Procedures for Sea Urchin Material
Collection and Care of Animals
Animals should be collected and transported with a minimum of mechanical
agitation or temperature shock to avoid undesired spawning. Since spawning in sea
urchins is often epidemic any spawning individual should be removed immediately from
the Collection or storage containers.
i Determination of the Sex
The sea urchins are dioecious and the two sexes of most species cannot be
distinguished by external examination. Therefore, sexes must be determined by
examination of the gonads or gametes (see below). On rare occasions an hermaphrodite
sea urchin may be found.
Temperature
The seasonal variation of surface water temperature is, of course, locale-
dependent. In general, handling of eggs and embryos should be done at sea water table
temperatures. Strongylacentrotus purpuratus should be handled at ~l5?C.
Spawning Induction
Two methods are in general use. The method of choice will vary depending upon
the amount of gametes required and the purpose for which they are intended.
Method l: This depends upon the fact that isotonic KCI (0.5 M) causes contraction of the
muscles of the gonads, with consequent shedding of gametes through the duct system.
Draw up about 0.75-1.0 ml of KCI in a syringe and inject into the perivisceral cavity
through the peristomeal membranes. Inject in two or three sites, 0.25-0.5 ml to a site.
Quickly invert females over a beaker of clean Millipore filtered sea water (MFSW) to
collect eggs. (NCTE: The filters should be first rinsed with distilled water to remove
the detergent used as a wetting agent.) The eggs should not be permitted to come into
contact with air. Collect sperm "dry", without dilution, as extruded, using a Pasteur
pipette. Fertilizable life of sperm of echinoderms decreases as semen is diluted with sea
water. Transfer sperm to a test tube on ice.
Method 2: Sea urchins are induced to shed by electrical stimulation. The effectiveness
of the method varies with the species. Arbacia and S. purpuratus respond readily.
Lytechinus, poorly. Place electrodes (from 10-25 A.C. source) on the test of the sea
urchin in the aboral ectoderm region. In 0.5-l minute gametes will flow from the
onadopores and may be drawn up in a pipette. The animal may be exposed to air
gpreferable for males) (Cautionl Lytechinus are very susceptible to drying in air and
should be kept wet) or emersed in sea water (females) during this procedure. This is the
method of choice for routine sexing or when a small amount of material is needed, for
the animals shed only while the current is passing through them.
EHD:Franks2 (6/9/88)
